entry.value: Shows how to view an interactive network visualization that was created with the pyvis library.

import knime.scripting.io as knio%%00010%%00010# NOTE:%%00010# This example requires packages that are not part of the bundled Python environment.%%00010# Please use an environment with the packages "pyvis" and "networkx" installed.%%00010%%00010from pyvis.network import Network%%00010import networkx as nx%%00010%%00010# Create an example graph using Networkx%%00010# See https://pyvis.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorial.html#networkx-integration%%00010nx_graph = nx.cycle_graph(10)%%00010nx_graph.nodes[1]['title'] = 'Number 1'%%00010nx_graph.nodes[1]['group'] = 1%%00010nx_graph.nodes[3]['title'] = 'I belong to a different group!'%%00010nx_graph.nodes[3]['group'] = 10%%00010nx_graph.add_node(20, size=20, title='couple', group=2)%%00010nx_graph.add_node(21, size=15, title='couple', group=2)%%00010nx_graph.add_edge(20, 21, weight=5)%%00010nx_graph.add_node(25, size=25, label='lonely', title='lonely node', group=3)%%00010%%00010# Create a pyvis network and generate an HTML page for it%%00010nt = Network("600px", cdn_resources="remote")%%00010nt.from_nx(nx_graph)%%00010graph_html = nt.generate_html()%%00010%%00010# To determine the type of the view the HTML document has to start with "<!DOCTYPE html>"%%00010# Alternatively, knio.view_html can be used%%00010knio.output_view = knio.view(f"<!DOCTYPE html>\n{graph_html}") # alternative: knio.view_html(graph_html)%%00010
